title: Introduction to Poetry — Rhyme and Rhythm
description: Students explore the world of poetry, learning about rhyme schemes and rhythmic patterns (meter). They read and listen to poems, identify rhyming words, and clap out rhythms to feel the beat of language.
instructions:
1. Ask: 'What makes a poem different from a story?' Discuss: poems use rhythm, rhyme, line breaks, and vivid language.
2. Read several short poems aloud. Have students listen for rhyming words.
3. Introduce rhyme scheme notation: label the last word's sound with a letter (AABB, ABAB, ABCB).
4. Practice identifying rhyme schemes in 3-4 short poems.
5. Introduce rhythm/meter: clap the beats. Some syllables are stressed (strong), some unstressed (weak).
6. Clap out the rhythm of 'Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star' — da DUM da DUM da DUM da DUM.
7. Students copy a favorite poem and mark the rhyme scheme and stressed syllables.
materials_needed: Colored pencils for marking rhyme schemes

slides.setup_instructions: Select 5-6 short poems with clear rhyme and rhythm. Include at least one limerick, one AABB poem, and one ABAB poem.

slides.text: 'Today we enter the world of poetry! Poems are different from stories. They use the SOUND of language — rhythm and rhyme — to create beauty and meaning. Listen to this poem...' Read a short rhyming poem aloud. 'Did you hear words that sounded alike? Those are RHYMES.'

'We can map the rhyme pattern using letters. If the first line ends with cat, that is A. The next line ends with dog — a different sound, so that is B. The third ends with hat — that rhymes with cat, so it is A again! This is called the RHYME SCHEME.' Practice with 2-3 poems.

'Poems also have RHYTHM — a beat, like music. Let us clap the rhythm of Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star: da-DUM da-DUM da-DUM da-DUM. The DUM syllables are stronger. This beat makes the poem feel musical.' Clap the rhythm of several poems together.

slides.prompt: Choose your favorite poem from the collection. Copy it into your journal. Mark the rhyme scheme with colored letters (A, B, C). Then underline the stressed (strong) syllables. Finally, practice reading the poem aloud with expression.

slides.text: Poems use rhyme and rhythm to make language musical. Rhyme scheme tells us the pattern of sounds at the ends of lines. Rhythm is the beat of the poem. This week, we will read more poems and write our own!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify rhyming words, label a simple rhyme scheme, and clap the rhythm of a poem?

parent_notes: Poetry is a wonderful way to develop language awareness. Reading poems aloud is essential — poetry is meant to be heard. Encourage your child to read poems with expression and feeling. Good poetry collections for this age: Shel Silverstein, Jack Prelutsky, and Mary Ann Hoberman. Nursery rhymes are also excellent for studying rhyme scheme and meter.

title: Measurement — Length in Metric Units
description: Students learn to measure length using metric units: centimeters, meters, and kilometers. They practice measuring real objects, estimating lengths, and understanding the relationships between units.
instructions:
1. Introduce the metric system: used by most of the world. Based on powers of 10.
2. Show a centimeter on a ruler. 'About the width of your pinky fingernail.'
3. Show a meter stick. '100 centimeters = 1 meter. About the distance from the floor to a doorknob.'
4. Discuss kilometers: 1,000 meters = 1 kilometer. Used for long distances (like the Silk Road!).
5. Practice measuring: pencil (cm), desk (cm), room (m), hallway (m).
6. Estimation game: estimate before measuring. How close were you?
7. Record measurements in a chart. Practice converting: 150 cm = 1 m 50 cm = 1.50 m.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather 8-10 objects of varying sizes to measure. Prepare a recording chart with columns: object, estimate, actual measurement.

slides.text: 'Most of the world uses the METRIC system for measuring. It is based on the number 10, which makes it easy to convert between units. The basic unit of length is the METER.' Show a meter stick. 'This is one meter — about the height of a doorknob from the floor.'

'A meter can be divided into 100 equal parts called CENTIMETERS. Centi means hundred, like century or cent.' Show on the ruler. 'Your pinky fingernail is about 1 centimeter wide. Now, for really long distances, we use KILOMETERS: 1 kilometer = 1,000 meters. Kilo means thousand.'

'Let us practice! First, ESTIMATE — guess how long something is before measuring. Then measure carefully: line up the zero mark of the ruler with one end of the object. Read the number at the other end.' Demonstrate measuring a pencil, a book, and the desk.

slides.prompt: Measure 8 objects: first estimate the length in cm or m, then measure precisely. Record in your chart. Include: a pencil, a book, a shoe, the table width, the room length, and 3 objects of your choice. Convert each measurement: how many cm? How many m?

slides.text: The metric system: 10 millimeters = 1 centimeter, 100 centimeters = 1 meter, 1,000 meters = 1 kilometer. Everything is based on 10! Remember: a centimeter is about a pinky nail, a meter is about a doorknob's height, a kilometer is about a 10-minute walk.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student measure objects accurately in centimeters and meters and state the basic metric conversions?

parent_notes: Measurement is one of the most practical math skills. The metric system is used worldwide in science and by most countries. Encourage measuring at home: furniture, rooms, toys. The estimation step is crucial — it builds number sense and prevents recording errors (if you estimate 30 cm and measure 300, something is wrong). Connect to decimals: 1.50 m = 150 cm.

title: Ancient Greece — City-States and Democracy
description: Students learn about Ancient Greece and its unique political structure of independent city-states (polis). They focus on Athens and Sparta as contrasting examples and explore the birth of democracy in Athens.
instructions:
1. Place Ancient Greece on the timeline: roughly 800-300 BCE, overlapping with late ancient China.
2. Show Greece on the map: mountainous peninsula with many islands.
3. Explain city-states: Greece was NOT one country but many small, independent cities (polis), each with its own government.
4. Compare Athens and Sparta: Athens valued education, art, and debate. Sparta valued military strength.
5. Introduce democracy: demos (people) + kratos (rule). Athens let adult male citizens vote on laws directly.
6. Discuss limitations: women, slaves, and foreigners could NOT vote.
7. Students create a Venn diagram comparing Athens and Sparta.
materials_needed: Map of Ancient Greece showing city-states

slides.setup_instructions: Have the timeline updated with China. Print a map of Ancient Greece showing major city-states. Prepare Athens vs. Sparta comparison notes.

slides.text: 'From China, we travel westward to GREECE! Look at the map: Greece is a mountainous peninsula surrounded by sea, with hundreds of islands. The mountains made travel between areas very difficult, so Greek communities became independent CITY-STATES — each one like a tiny country with its own government, army, and laws.'

'The two most famous city-states were ATHENS and SPARTA. Athens loved learning, art, theater, and debate. Children studied reading, music, and philosophy. Sparta was completely different — it was a warrior society. Boys left home at age 7 to train as soldiers! Both were powerful, but in very different ways.'

'Athens gave the world something incredible: DEMOCRACY. This word comes from Greek: demos means people, kratos means rule. In Athens, adult male citizens could vote DIRECTLY on every law. They gathered on a hill and debated and voted. Our own government is based on this idea! But Athens's democracy was limited — women, enslaved people, and foreigners could not vote.'

slides.prompt: Create a Venn diagram comparing Athens and Sparta. In the Athens circle: education, arts, democracy, philosophy, navy. In the Sparta circle: military training, strict discipline, powerful army, boys trained from age 7. In the overlap: both were Greek, both had slaves, both were powerful city-states.

slides.text: Ancient Greece was not one country but many city-states. Athens gave us democracy — the idea that citizens should have a say in their government. Sparta showed the power of discipline and training. Both influenced the world we live in today.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain what a city-state is, compare Athens and Sparta, and describe the basic concept of Athenian democracy?

parent_notes: Ancient Greece is foundational to Western civilization. The concept of democracy is particularly relevant — discuss how our government is similar to and different from Athenian democracy (we vote for representatives rather than on every law directly). The Athens vs. Sparta comparison is engaging for children. Ask: 'Which city-state would you rather live in and why?' Be sure to discuss the limitations of Greek democracy honestly.

title: Greece and the Mediterranean — Islands, Peninsulas, and Seas
description: Students explore the geography of Greece and the broader Mediterranean region. They learn geographic terms (peninsula, archipelago, strait) and understand how the sea shaped Greek civilization.
instructions:
1. Show Greece on the map: the Balkan Peninsula, Peloponnese Peninsula, and the Greek islands.
2. Vocabulary: peninsula (land surrounded by water on three sides), island, archipelago (group of islands), strait (narrow water passage).
3. Identify key seas: Mediterranean, Aegean, Ionian.
4. Discuss how geography shaped Greece: mountains divided people into city-states; the sea connected them for trade and travel.
5. The Greeks were skilled sailors — the Mediterranean was their highway.
6. Students label a map of Greece: mainland, Peloponnese, Crete, Aegean Sea, Ionian Sea, Mediterranean Sea.
7. Draw and label landform vocabulary: peninsula, island, archipelago, strait.
materials_needed: Map of Greece and the Mediterranean

slides.setup_instructions: Print blank outline maps of Greece. Display a large reference map of the Mediterranean region. Prepare vocabulary definition cards.

slides.text: 'Look at Greece on the map. What do you notice? It is almost completely surrounded by water! Greece sits on a PENINSULA — land that juts out into the sea, with water on three sides. It also has HUNDREDS of islands scattered through the Aegean Sea. A group of islands is called an ARCHIPELAGO.'

'Three seas surround Greece: the AEGEAN SEA to the east (between Greece and Turkey), the IONIAN SEA to the west, and the great MEDITERRANEAN SEA to the south. The word Mediterranean means middle of the land — it sits between Europe, Africa, and Asia.' Point to each on the map.

'This geography made the Greeks incredible sailors. No place in Greece is more than about 85 miles from the sea! The mountains made overland travel very hard, but the sea was smooth and fast. Greek ships carried olive oil, pottery, and wine to trade all around the Mediterranean.'

slides.prompt: On your outline map: (1) Color the Aegean Sea light blue, the Ionian Sea medium blue, and the Mediterranean dark blue. (2) Label the mainland, Peloponnese peninsula, and the island of Crete. (3) Mark Athens and Sparta. (4) On the back, draw and define: peninsula, island, archipelago, and strait.

slides.text: Greece's geography — mountains, peninsulas, islands, and surrounding seas — shaped its entire civilization. The mountains divided people into independent city-states. The sea connected them to each other and to the wider world. Geography is destiny!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the major seas, peninsulas, and islands of Greece and define peninsula, island, archipelago, and strait?

parent_notes: The geographic vocabulary in this lesson (peninsula, archipelago, strait) is important and will recur throughout geography studies. The key insight is that geography shapes civilization: Greece's mountains created political fragmentation (city-states), while its access to the sea enabled trade and cultural exchange. Compare to China, which was large and unified, and Egypt, which was defined by a single river.

title: Read Aloud — Greek Mythology: Theseus and the Minotaur
description: A read-aloud of the myth of Theseus and the Minotaur, introducing students to Greek mythology. They discuss the role of myths in ancient cultures and the themes of bravery and cleverness.
instructions:
1. Introduction: 'The Greeks told stories about gods, heroes, and monsters to explain the world around them. These stories are called MYTHS.'
2. Set the context: King Minos of Crete, the Labyrinth, the Minotaur (half-man, half-bull).
3. Read the myth aloud with expression and dramatic pauses.
4. Discuss: What qualities did Theseus show? (bravery, cleverness). How did Ariadne help? (the thread).
5. Connect to geography: Crete is the largest Greek island, the Aegean Sea.
6. Students illustrate a key scene and write a character description of Theseus.
7. Preview: more mythology throughout the week.

slides.setup_instructions: Select an age-appropriate retelling of Theseus and the Minotaur. 'D'Aulaires Book of Greek Myths' is an excellent resource. Have Crete located on the map.

slides.text: 'The Ancient Greeks told amazing stories about gods who lived on Mount Olympus, heroes with incredible strength, and monsters. These stories are called MYTHS. Myths helped the Greeks explain things they did not understand and taught lessons about life. Today: the story of Theseus and the Minotaur!'

Read the myth aloud. Pause at key moments: 'The Minotaur lives in a LABYRINTH — a maze so complicated that no one who enters can find their way out. Theseus volunteers to go in. Would you be brave enough?' Build tension and drama as the story unfolds.

After reading: 'What made Theseus a hero? Was it just his strength, or also his cleverness? Who helped him? Ariadne gave him a ball of thread to unwind as he walked, so he could follow it back out. Sometimes being smart is more important than being strong.'

slides.prompt: Draw the most exciting scene from the myth. Below your illustration, write a character description of Theseus: what he looks like (use your imagination), his personality traits, and why he is considered a hero. Include at least 3 descriptive adjectives.

slides.text: Greek myths have been told for over 2,500 years and are still popular today! They are full of adventure, bravery, and wisdom. This week we will hear more myths and learn about the heroes and gods of Ancient Greece.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student retell the key events of the Theseus myth and identify the hero's character traits?

parent_notes: Greek mythology is endlessly engaging for children this age. 'D'Aulaires Book of Greek Myths' is considered the gold standard for children's mythology. The myths contain mature themes (violence, deception) but age-appropriate retellings handle them well. Myths connect to literature, art, astronomy (constellations), and language (words like labyrinth, odyssey, Achilles heel). This is just the beginning!

title: Poetry — Free Verse and Writing Original Poems
description: Students learn about free verse poetry — poetry that does not follow strict rhyme or meter rules. They compare free verse to structured poetry and write their own free verse poems about nature or Ancient Greece.
instructions:
1. Read two poems: one with strict rhyme and meter, one in free verse.
2. Compare: free verse has no required rhyme scheme, no fixed rhythm. It focuses on imagery and emotion.
3. But free verse is NOT just chopped-up prose — it uses line breaks purposefully, creates rhythm through repetition, and relies on vivid images.
4. Read examples of free verse: show how line breaks create pauses and emphasis.
5. Brainstorm topics: nature, the Greek islands, a character from mythology, the sea.
6. Write a free verse poem together as a class.
7. Students write their own free verse poem (at least 8 lines).
materials_needed: Examples of rhyming and free verse poems

items: Rhyming and free verse poem examples
slides.setup_instructions: Select 3-4 free verse poems and 1-2 rhyming poems for comparison. Choose poems with strong imagery and accessible language.

slides.text: 'Yesterday we studied rhyme and rhythm. Today we discover poetry that breaks those rules — FREE VERSE! Free verse does not have to rhyme. It does not have to follow a strict rhythm. But it IS still poetry because it uses powerful images, careful word choice, and purposeful line breaks.' Read a free verse example.

'Why does the poet break the line HERE instead of there? Because the pause makes you THINK about the words. Watch...' Write a sentence on the board as prose, then rewrite it as free verse with deliberate line breaks. Show how the breaks change the feeling. 'Line breaks are a tool — like punctuation for the eyes and ears.'

'Let us write a free verse poem together about the Aegean Sea. Close your eyes. Imagine standing on a cliff in Greece, looking at the blue water and white islands. What do you see, hear, smell, feel?' Write the collaborative poem on the board, shaping student suggestions into poetic lines.

slides.prompt: Write your own free verse poem (at least 8 lines). Choose a topic: the Greek islands, a hero from mythology, the sea, a storm, or any scene from nature. Use at least 2 vivid images (describe something using your senses). Think carefully about where you break each line.

slides.text: Free verse gives you freedom to focus on images and feelings without worrying about making words rhyme. The poet Mary Oliver said: 'Poetry is a life-cherishing force.' Your poems capture moments and feelings in a way that prose cannot. Keep writing!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain the difference between free verse and structured poetry and write an original free verse poem?

parent_notes: Free verse is liberating for young writers because it removes the pressure of rhyming. Some children struggle with rhyming poetry (it can lead to forced, unnatural phrasing), but free verse allows them to focus on what matters most: images and feelings. Encourage your child to use sensory details — what they see, hear, taste, touch, and smell. Read free verse poems at bedtime this week.

title: Measurement — Converting Metric Length Units
description: Students practice converting between centimeters, meters, and kilometers using the relationships they learned. They use multiplication and division by 10, 100, and 1000.
instructions:
1. Review the metric relationships: 1 km = 1,000 m, 1 m = 100 cm, 1 cm = 10 mm.
2. Create a metric staircase visual: km at top, m in middle, cm and mm at bottom.
3. Going DOWN the stairs (bigger to smaller unit) = MULTIPLY. Going UP (smaller to bigger) = DIVIDE.
4. Practice: 3 m = ? cm (3 x 100 = 300 cm). 500 cm = ? m (500 / 100 = 5 m).
5. Mixed practice: 2 km = ? m, 4,500 m = ? km, 250 cm = ? m.
6. Connect to decimals: 150 cm = 1.50 m, 2.5 km = 2,500 m.
7. Word problems involving conversion.
materials_needed: Ruler and meter stick for reference

slides.setup_instructions: Draw a large metric staircase on the board or poster: km at top, m, cm, mm at bottom. Show the x10/x100/x1000 multipliers on each step.

slides.text: 'Yesterday we measured in centimeters and meters. Today we learn to CONVERT between units. Think of it like a staircase: kilometers at the top, meters in the middle, centimeters below, millimeters at the bottom. Each step is times 10, 100, or 1,000.'

'Going DOWN the stairs means going to a smaller unit — you MULTIPLY because you need MORE small units. 3 meters = 3 x 100 = 300 centimeters. Going UP the stairs means going to a bigger unit — you DIVIDE because you need FEWER big units. 500 cm = 500 / 100 = 5 m.'

'Here is where decimals connect! 150 cm = 1.50 m (move the decimal point two places left). 2.5 km = 2,500 m (move the decimal point three places right). The metric system and decimals are best friends!' Practice several examples together.

slides.prompt: Convert: (1) 7 m = ? cm, (2) 800 cm = ? m, (3) 4 km = ? m, (4) 3,000 m = ? km, (5) 250 cm = ? m, (6) 1.5 m = ? cm, (7) 2.3 km = ? m. Word problem: The Silk Road was about 6,400 km long. How many meters is that?

slides.text: Converting metric units is easy because everything is based on 10! To go from a bigger unit to a smaller one, multiply. To go from smaller to bigger, divide. The metric staircase is your best tool for remembering.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student convert between centimeters, meters, and kilometers using multiplication and division?

parent_notes: Metric conversion is essentially an exercise in multiplying and dividing by powers of 10, which connects directly to decimals. If your child struggles with the abstract conversions, use the ruler and meter stick to make it concrete: lay out 100 cm and show that this IS 1 meter. The 'staircase' visual is very effective — draw it on a card for your child to reference.

title: Invertebrates — Arachnids and Crustaceans
description: Students learn about two more groups of arthropods: arachnids (spiders, scorpions, ticks) and crustaceans (crabs, lobsters, shrimp). They compare body structures and habitats.
instructions:
1. Review insects: 3 body parts, 6 legs. Now meet their arthropod cousins!
2. Arachnids: 2 body parts (cephalothorax and abdomen), 8 legs, no wings, no antennae.
3. Examples: spiders, scorpions, ticks, mites. Most are predators.
4. Spider specialty: spinning silk webs to catch prey. Different web types.
5. Crustaceans: hard shell (exoskeleton), 10 or more legs, 2 pairs of antennae, mostly aquatic.
6. Examples: crabs, lobsters, shrimp, barnacles, pill bugs (the only common land crustacean!).
7. Students create a comparison chart: insects vs. arachnids vs. crustaceans.
8. Draw a detailed spider with labels.
materials_needed: Optional: preserved specimens or plastic models

slides.setup_instructions: Print clear images of spiders, scorpions, crabs, lobsters, and pill bugs. Prepare a blank comparison chart with rows for: body parts, legs, antennae, wings, habitat.

slides.text: 'Remember our rule: 3 body parts + 6 legs = insect. But what about spiders? They have 8 legs! Spiders belong to a group called ARACHNIDS. They have only 2 body parts: the CEPHALOTHORAX (head and chest fused together) and the ABDOMEN. Eight legs, no wings, no antennae.'

'Arachnids include spiders, scorpions, ticks, and mites. Most are predators. Spiders are famous for spinning silk webs — one of the strongest natural materials! Different spiders build different webs: orb webs (wheel-shaped), funnel webs, sheet webs, and cobwebs.' Show images of web types.

'Now meet the CRUSTACEANS: crabs, lobsters, shrimp, and barnacles. They have a hard outer shell called an exoskeleton, 10 or more legs, and 2 pairs of antennae. Most live in water. But here is a surprise: PILL BUGS (roly-polies) are crustaceans too — they are the most common land crustacean!' Show a pill bug image.

slides.prompt: Complete the comparison chart for insects, arachnids, and crustaceans. Include: number of body parts, number of legs, antennae (yes/no), wings (yes/no), and habitat. Then draw a detailed labeled diagram of a spider showing: cephalothorax, abdomen, 8 legs, spinnerets, fangs, and eyes (most have 8!).

slides.text: Insects, arachnids, and crustaceans are all ARTHROPODS — animals with jointed legs and exoskeletons. But they differ in body structure: insects have 6 legs, arachnids have 8, and crustaceans have 10 or more. Next time: mollusks — animals with soft bodies!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student distinguish between insects, arachnids, and crustaceans based on body structure, legs, and other features?

parent_notes: Children often lump spiders and insects together, but they are quite different groups. The 8-legs rule is the easiest way to identify arachnids. Pill bugs (roly-polies) being crustaceans is a great 'wow' fact — they are more closely related to crabs than to insects! If you can safely observe a spider web in your yard, this is a wonderful nature study opportunity. Never touch unknown spiders.

title: Greek Art — Pottery and Geometric Designs
description: Students explore ancient Greek pottery art, learning about red-figure and black-figure techniques. They create their own Greek-inspired pottery designs on paper plates or terracotta-colored paper.
instructions:
1. Show images of Greek pottery: amphorae, kraters, kylixes. Discuss their uses (wine, water, oil storage).
2. Two main styles: black-figure (black images on red clay) and red-figure (red images on black background).
3. Common images: myths, battles, daily life, athletes, gods.
4. Show Greek geometric border patterns: meanders (Greek key), waves, palmettes.
5. Demonstrate drawing a Greek key border pattern step by step.
6. Students design their own Greek vase on terracotta-colored paper or a paper plate:
   - Draw the vase shape
   - Add a scene (myth, Olympics, daily life)
   - Add geometric border patterns
7. Use black marker on terracotta paper for black-figure style.

slides.setup_instructions: Print images of Greek pottery in both black-figure and red-figure styles. Cut terracotta paper into vase shapes, or use paper plates. Have Greek key pattern examples displayed.

slides.text: 'The Ancient Greeks were master potters. They made beautiful vases, jars, and cups from clay, then painted them with incredible scenes. Greek pottery tells us stories about their daily life, their myths, and their values.' Show examples of different pottery shapes and their uses.

'Two main painting styles: BLACK-FIGURE — black paint on the natural red-orange clay, and RED-FIGURE — the background is painted black, leaving the figures in the natural clay color. Red-figure was newer and allowed more detail.' Show side-by-side examples.

'Greek vases also have beautiful geometric borders. The most famous is the GREEK KEY pattern — also called a meander.' Demonstrate step-by-step on the board: draw a straight line, add right angles turning in, then back out, repeating the pattern. 'Let us practice this border before designing our vases.'

slides.prompt: Design your own Greek vase on terracotta paper or a paper plate: (1) Draw the vase shape. (2) Add a scene in the center — a myth, an athletic event, or daily life in Greece. (3) Add Greek key borders at the top and bottom. Use black marker for the black-figure style.

slides.text: Greek pottery is both art and history. The scenes painted on vases are one of our best windows into daily life in Ancient Greece. Your vases capture the style and spirit of an art form that is over 2,500 years old! The Greek key pattern is still used in architecture and fashion today.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe Greek pottery styles and create a vase design with a scene and geometric border?

parent_notes: Greek pottery is one of the most distinctive art forms of the ancient world. The Greek key (meander) pattern is excellent for developing fine motor skills and understanding geometric patterns. If you visit an art museum, look for Greek pottery in the antiquities section. Many museums have extensive collections. The stories on the vases provide a wonderful connection to mythology.

title: Sewing — Running Stitch and Cross Stitch
description: Students learn basic hand sewing with a focus on the running stitch and the cross stitch. They practice on burlap or loosely woven fabric, developing fine motor skills, patience, and concentration.
instructions:
1. Discuss sewing throughout history: one of the oldest human skills. Greeks wove fabric and sewed garments.
2. Safety: handle needles carefully, use a thimble, always know where the needle is.
3. Thread the needle: demonstrate with a large-eye tapestry needle and yarn/embroidery floss.
4. Running stitch: in and out, in and out, keeping stitches even. Practice on burlap.
5. Cross stitch: two diagonal stitches crossing over each other. Practice making a row of X's.
6. Project: sew a simple design (their initial, a simple shape) using running stitch or cross stitch.
7. Clean up: count needles to make sure none are lost.

slides.heading: Practical Life
slides.subheading: Hand Sewing — Running and Cross Stitch

slides.setup_instructions: Pre-cut fabric into manageable squares. Thread several needles in advance for younger students. Have a finished sample to show.

slides.text: 'Sewing is one of the oldest human skills — people have been sewing for over 20,000 years! The Greeks wore beautiful woven garments. Today we learn two basic stitches that you can use to create art and repair clothing.'

'First: thread the needle. Push the thread through the eye and pull it so you have a tail about as long as your arm. Tie a knot at the end. Now the RUNNING STITCH: push the needle UP through the fabric, then DOWN a short distance away, then UP again.' Demonstrate slowly. 'Keep your stitches even and straight.'

'The CROSS STITCH makes an X. First, come up at the bottom left, go down at the top right — that is half the X. Then come up at the bottom right and go down at the top left. You have made an X! A row of these creates a beautiful pattern.' Demonstrate slowly on the fabric.

slides.prompt: Practice 10 running stitches in a straight line. Then practice 5 cross stitches in a row. Once comfortable, choose a simple design (your initial letter, a heart, a star) and sew it using your choice of stitch. Take your time — neatness matters more than speed!

slides.text: Sewing develops patience, concentration, and fine motor skills. You learned two stitches today that have been used for thousands of years. With practice, you can create beautiful designs, mend clothing, and even make gifts. Always count your needles before putting supplies away!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student thread a needle, tie a knot, and execute a running stitch and a basic cross stitch?

parent_notes: Sewing is a quintessential Montessori practical life activity. Use blunt-tipped tapestry needles for safety. Burlap or Aida cloth has visible holes that make it easy for beginners. Start with yarn, which is easier to see and handle than thread. The key is patience — many children want to rush. Emphasize that careful, even stitches come with practice. This skill builds the same focus and fine motor control as handwriting.

title: Poetry — Writing Rhyming Poems
description: Students practice writing structured rhyming poems. They learn the limerick and couplet forms, brainstorm rhyming word lists, and compose their own rhyming poems.
instructions:
1. Review rhyme schemes from Day 1.
2. Introduce the COUPLET: two lines that rhyme (AA). 'Roses are red, violets are blue...' is a famous couplet pattern.
3. Write couplets together: pick an end word, brainstorm rhymes, compose the two lines.
4. Introduce the LIMERICK: 5 lines, AABBA rhyme scheme, humorous.
5. Read several limericks. Clap the rhythm: da DUM da da DUM da da DUM (lines 1,2,5), da DUM da da DUM (lines 3,4).
6. Write a limerick together.
7. Students write: 3 original couplets and 1 original limerick.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare lists of common rhyming word families. Select 4-5 limericks and several couplets as examples.

slides.text: 'Today we write poems with RHYME! The simplest rhyming form is a COUPLET — just two lines that rhyme. Here is one: The Greeks sailed across the blue sea / To find the adventure that set their hearts free. Two lines, one rhyme. Simple and satisfying!'

'A LIMERICK is a funny 5-line poem with a special rhyme scheme: AABBA. Lines 1, 2, and 5 rhyme with each other, and lines 3 and 4 rhyme with each other. Limericks are always humorous!' Read several examples. Clap the rhythm together.

'Let us write a limerick together! Line 1 introduces a character: There once was a hero named Theseus. Now we need words that rhyme with Theseus... Let us brainstorm. Lines 3 and 4 are shorter. Line 5 is the punchline — the funny twist!' Compose together on the board.

slides.prompt: Write 3 original couplets (pairs of rhyming lines) about any topic. Then write 1 original limerick (5 lines, AABBA). Start by brainstorming rhyming words before writing. Remember: limericks should be funny! Share your favorite one with the group.

slides.text: Couplets are the building blocks of rhyming poetry. Limericks show how structure and humor can work together. The trick to rhyming poetry: pick your rhyming words FIRST, then build the lines around them. Poetry is play with language!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student write a couplet with proper rhyme and compose a limerick with the correct AABBA structure?

parent_notes: Limericks are incredibly fun for children and teach valuable lessons about poetic structure. The challenge is finding rhyming words that make sense — this builds vocabulary and creative thinking. If your child struggles with rhymes, use a rhyming dictionary or brainstorm word families together (cat, hat, bat, sat, flat, that). Edward Lear's original limericks are wonderful to read aloud.

title: Measurement — Estimating and Measuring in Context
description: Students apply their measurement skills to real-world estimation and measurement challenges. They practice choosing the appropriate unit (mm, cm, m, km) for different situations.
instructions:
1. Choosing the right unit: 'Would you measure a pencil in kilometers? Of course not! Choosing the right unit is important.'
2. Matching game: match objects/distances to the best unit (ant = mm, book = cm, room = m, city to city = km).
3. Estimation challenge: show 10 objects, students estimate length in the appropriate unit before measuring.
4. Measurement scavenger hunt: students find objects that are approximately 1 cm, 10 cm, 30 cm, 1 m.
5. Multi-step problems: 'If 3 books are each 25 cm long, what is their total length? How much is that in meters?'
6. Connect to history: 'The Parthenon is about 70 m long. How many meter sticks would that be?'

slides.setup_instructions: Gather 10 objects of varying sizes. Prepare matching cards: objects on one set, units on another. Set up a scavenger hunt around the room/house.

slides.text: 'A good mathematician knows which tool and unit to use. You would not measure an ant in kilometers or the distance to another city in millimeters! Let us practice choosing the RIGHT unit.' Sort objects/distances into categories: mm, cm, m, or km.

'Now let us sharpen our estimation skills. Good estimators use BENCHMARKS — things they already know. Your pinky nail is about 1 cm. Your arm span is about 1 m. A 10-minute walk is about 1 km. Use these benchmarks to estimate other things!' Practice with 3 objects.

'Now a scavenger hunt! Find something that is about 1 cm long, something about 10 cm, something about 30 cm, and something about 1 m. Estimate first, then measure to check. How close were your estimates?' Guide the activity.

slides.prompt: Measurement scavenger hunt: find and measure objects that are approximately 1 cm, 5 cm, 10 cm, 30 cm, 50 cm, and 1 m. Record your estimate and actual measurement. Then solve: If 4 pencils are each 18 cm long and placed end to end, what is the total length in cm? In meters?

slides.text: Choosing the right unit and estimating accurately are real-world skills you will use every day. Remember your benchmarks: pinky nail = 1 cm, arm span = 1 m, 10-minute walk = 1 km. Practice estimating whenever you can — it makes you a stronger mathematician!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student select appropriate units for different situations and estimate lengths with reasonable accuracy?

parent_notes: Estimation is one of the most practical math skills. Encourage your child to estimate before measuring anything — whether it is furniture, distances, or ingredients. The benchmark strategy (using known measurements as reference points) is powerful. Make estimation a daily game: 'How tall do you think that tree is? How wide is the driveway?' Then measure to check.

title: Ancient Greece — Athenian Democracy and City-States
description: Students learn about the ancient Olympic Games: their religious origins, the events, the athletes, and the tradition of the Olympic truce. They compare ancient and modern Olympics.
instructions:
1. The Olympics began in Olympia, Greece, in 776 BCE — over 2,700 years ago!
2. The games honored Zeus, king of the gods. Held every 4 years.
3. Events: foot races (stadion), wrestling, boxing, chariot racing, pentathlon (5 events).
4. Athletes competed NAKED (the word 'gymnasium' comes from Greek gymnos = naked). Only men.
5. The Olympic truce: all wars stopped during the games so athletes could travel safely.
6. Modern Olympics: revived in 1896. Now include women, many more sports, many countries.
7. Students create a comparison poster: Ancient vs. Modern Olympics.
8. Design their own Olympic event.
materials_needed: Images of ancient and modern Olympics

items: Images of ancient and modern Olympics
slides.setup_instructions: Locate Olympia on the map of Greece. Gather images comparing ancient Olympic events (from pottery) with modern Olympics photos.

slides.text: 'The Olympic Games are the most famous sporting event in the world — and they began right here in Ancient Greece! In 776 BCE, athletes from all over Greece gathered at a place called OLYMPIA to compete in honor of Zeus, the king of the gods. The games happened every four years.'

'Ancient Olympic events included the STADION (a sprint of about 200 meters — our word stadium comes from this!), wrestling, boxing, chariot racing, and the PENTATHLON (five events: running, jumping, throwing the discus, throwing the javelin, and wrestling). Only free Greek men could compete. The winners received olive wreaths, not gold medals!'

'One of the most amazing Olympic traditions was the TRUCE. All wars between Greek city-states stopped during the games so that athletes and spectators could travel safely. Imagine: even Athens and Sparta stopped fighting! Today's Olympics still promote peace. The modern Olympics began in 1896 and now include over 200 countries, women athletes, and hundreds of sports.'

slides.prompt: Create a comparison poster: Ancient Olympics vs. Modern Olympics. Include categories: when, where, who competed, events, prizes, and traditions. Illustrate at least 3 ancient events and 3 modern events. Bonus: design your own new Olympic event and describe the rules!

slides.text: The Olympic Games connect us directly to Ancient Greece. The values of fair competition, athletic excellence, and international peace all come from the original Greek games. From a single footrace in 776 BCE to the global spectacle today — the Olympic spirit lives on!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the origins and events of the ancient Olympics and compare them to the modern games?

parent_notes: The Olympics are a topic children love because they connect ancient history to something they know from modern life. The Olympic truce is a particularly powerful concept — even enemies stopped fighting for the sake of sport. If possible, watch clips of both modern Olympic events and artistic recreations of ancient ones. The word origins are fun: stadium from stadion, gymnasium from gymnos.

title: Greek Mythology — Gods and Goddesses of Olympus
description: Students learn about the major Greek gods and goddesses: Zeus, Hera, Athena, Poseidon, Apollo, Artemis, and others. They explore the gods' domains, symbols, and roles in Greek religion and daily life.
instructions:
1. The Greeks believed in many gods (polytheism) who lived on Mount Olympus.
2. Introduce the 6 major Olympians: Zeus (king, lightning), Hera (queen, marriage), Poseidon (sea, trident), Athena (wisdom, owl), Apollo (sun, music, lyre), Artemis (moon, hunting, bow).
3. Each god had a domain, symbols, and personality. They acted like humans — jealous, loving, angry.
4. Greeks built temples to the gods, made offerings, and prayed for help.
5. Students create Greek God trading cards: name, domain, symbols, illustration, one myth.
materials_needed: Index cards or cardstock for trading cards
Images of Greek gods and their symbols

slides.setup_instructions: Print or display images of the major Olympian gods with their symbols. Pre-cut cardstock into trading card sizes (about 3x5 inches).

slides.text: 'The Greeks believed the world was ruled by powerful gods who lived on top of Mount Olympus, the tallest mountain in Greece. These gods looked like humans but were immortal — they could never die. They had incredible powers, but also very human emotions: love, jealousy, anger, and pride.'

'ZEUS was king of the gods — he threw lightning bolts! His wife HERA was goddess of marriage. POSEIDON ruled the seas with his trident. ATHENA was goddess of wisdom and war strategy — she was born from Zeus's head! APOLLO drove the sun chariot and played the lyre. His twin sister ARTEMIS was goddess of the moon and the hunt.'

'The Greeks built magnificent temples for their gods, like the Parthenon for Athena in Athens (the city was named after her!). They made offerings of food and wine, held festivals, and told myths about the gods' adventures. The gods were part of everyday life — Greeks might pray to Poseidon before a sea voyage or to Athena before an exam.'

slides.prompt: Create at least 4 Greek God trading cards. Each card should include: the god's name, their domain (what they rule), their symbols, a small illustration, and one sentence about a famous myth they appear in. Make them colorful and detailed! Trade with a friend when done.

slides.text: The Greek gods were like a divine family — powerful but imperfect, just like real families. Their stories (myths) helped the Greeks understand the world: why the seasons change, why earthquakes happen, why the sun rises. Many of our words come from the gods: cereal from Ceres, music from the Muses, echo from Echo.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student name at least 6 Greek gods/goddesses, their domains, and their symbols?

parent_notes: Greek mythology is endlessly fascinating for children. The trading card activity provides a fun way to organize information. Consider reading a myth each evening this week — there are wonderful collections for children. Connect the gods to modern references: Nike (goddess of victory), Apollo space missions, Poseidon Adventure, Hercules movies. The planets are named after Roman versions of Greek gods!

title: Read Aloud — The Story of the Olympics
description: A read-aloud about the Olympic Games, connecting the history lesson to a narrative about competition, sportsmanship, and the ancient Greek values of excellence and honor.
instructions:
1. Select a book about the Olympics (ancient or modern, or both).
2. Before reading: review the ancient Olympic events from history.
3. Read with expression, pausing for discussion about athletic values.
4. After reading: discuss sportsmanship. What does it mean to compete with honor?
5. Connect to Greek values: arete (excellence), time (honor), kleos (glory).
6. Students write about: 'If I competed in the ancient Olympics, I would choose [event] because...'
7. Share responses.

slides.setup_instructions: Select a book about the Olympics appropriate for ages 6-9. Preview for read-aloud pausing points. Have the ancient events list from history class visible.

slides.text: 'We learned about the ancient Olympics in history today. Now let us dive deeper through a story. Before we read, the Greeks had three important values: ARETE (striving for excellence), TIME (honor and respect), and KLEOS (glory that lives on after you). These values drove their athletes.'

Read the text aloud. Pause at key moments to discuss: 'Why did athletes train so hard? What did winning mean to them? It was not just about a medal — it was about bringing honor to their city-state and being remembered forever.'

After reading, discuss sportsmanship: 'What does it mean to compete with honor? Is winning the only thing that matters? The Greeks believed HOW you competed was just as important as whether you won. Even today, we admire athletes who show good sportsmanship.'

slides.prompt: In your journal, write a response: 'If I competed in the ancient Olympics, I would choose [event] because...' Describe your training, the competition, and whether you win or lose — and how you show good sportsmanship either way. Write at least one full paragraph.

slides.text: The Olympic spirit is about more than winning. It is about pushing yourself to be the best you can be, competing fairly, and respecting your opponents. These values from Ancient Greece are still important today in sports and in life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student articulate Greek athletic values and write a thoughtful response about competition and sportsmanship?

parent_notes: The Olympic theme naturally opens discussions about sportsmanship, hard work, and fair play — values that extend beyond athletics. The Greek concept of arete (striving for personal excellence) is particularly Montessori-aligned: it is about being your best self, not being better than others. This is a great opportunity to talk about effort vs. outcome.

title: Poetry — Haiku and Imagery
description: Students learn about haiku, the Japanese poetry form with a 5-7-5 syllable structure. They practice counting syllables, analyzing imagery in haiku, and writing their own haiku about nature.
instructions:
1. Introduce haiku: a Japanese form, but we connect it to poetry study.
2. Structure: 3 lines, 5-7-5 syllables. Count syllables by clapping.
3. Practice counting syllables in words: but-ter-fly (3), el-e-phant (3), cat (1), beau-ti-ful (3).
4. Read several haiku. Discuss: haiku capture a single moment in nature. They paint a picture with very few words.
5. The power of IMAGERY: using words that appeal to the senses (sight, sound, touch, smell, taste).
6. Write haiku together: choose a nature subject, brainstorm sensory words, fit them to 5-7-5.
7. Students write 3 original haiku about nature.
materials_needed: Collection of haiku (Basho, Issa are classic)

slides.setup_instructions: Select 6-8 classic haiku translated into English. Display nature photographs for inspiration. Have the syllable counting strategy reviewed.

slides.text: 'Today we travel to Japan for a special poetry form: HAIKU! A haiku has only three lines and follows a strict syllable pattern: 5 syllables in line 1, 7 syllables in line 2, and 5 syllables in line 3. That is only 17 syllables total! But a great haiku can paint an entire picture.'

'First, let us practice counting syllables. Clap each beat: wa-ter (2), moun-tain (2), but-ter-fly (3), el-e-phant (3). Now let us read this haiku by Basho: An old si-lent pond (5) / A frog jumps in-to the pond (7) / Splash! Si-lence a-gain (5). Can you see the picture? Can you HEAR the splash?'

'Haiku use IMAGERY — words that make you see, hear, feel, smell, or taste something. The best haiku capture one single moment in nature. Let us write one together. Our subject: a sunset. What do we see? What colors? What do we feel? Let us fit our best words into 5-7-5.' Compose on the board.

slides.prompt: Write 3 original haiku about nature. Choose different subjects: a season, an animal, weather, a flower, the ocean. Remember: 5-7-5 syllables. Use imagery — paint a picture with your words! Count syllables carefully by clapping. Illustrate your favorite haiku.

slides.text: Haiku show us that sometimes less is more. Just 17 syllables can capture a beautiful moment forever. The Japanese poet Basho said: 'Do not follow in the footsteps of the old poets — seek what they sought.' Find your own moments of beauty in nature!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student count syllables accurately and write original haiku following the 5-7-5 structure with nature imagery?

parent_notes: Haiku is perfect for young poets because the constraints are simple yet challenging. Counting syllables builds phonological awareness, and the imagery requirement develops descriptive writing skills. Go outside with your child and observe nature closely — this is the best inspiration for haiku. Traditional haiku include a seasonal reference (kigo). Basho, Issa, and Buson are the three great classical haiku masters.

title: Measurement — Word Problems with Length
description: Students solve multi-step word problems involving metric length measurement, conversion, and the four operations. Problems are set in historical and everyday contexts.
instructions:
1. Review conversion: cm to m and back.
2. Solve problems together, modeling the problem-solving process:
   - 'A Greek stadion track was about 192 meters long. How many centimeters is that?'
   - 'Three ribbon pieces measure 45 cm, 62 cm, and 38 cm. What is the total length? Convert to meters.'
3. Multi-step: 'A rope is 3 meters long. You cut off 85 cm. How much is left? (Convert to same unit first.)'
4. Comparison: 'Who jumped farther: Amir at 2.1 m or Sofia at 195 cm?'
5. Students solve 8 word problems independently.
6. Create their own measurement word problem.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 8-10 word problems of varying difficulty. Include problems with historical context (Greek measurements, Silk Road distances, Great Wall length).

slides.text: 'Today we use our measurement skills to solve real problems. Remember the problem-solving steps: (1) READ carefully, (2) IDENTIFY what you need to find, (3) DECIDE the operation, (4) CONVERT to the same unit if needed, (5) SOLVE, (6) CHECK if the answer makes sense.'

Model: 'A Greek stadion track was about 192 m. The Parthenon is 70 m long. How much longer is the track? 192 - 70 = 122 m longer. Check: 192 is roughly 200, 70 is roughly 70, 200 - 70 = 130. Our answer 122 is close, so it makes sense.'

Model a conversion problem: 'A rope is 3 m long. You cut off 85 cm. How much is left? First, make the units the same: 3 m = 300 cm. Now: 300 - 85 = 215 cm = 2 m 15 cm = 2.15 m. Always convert to the same unit before adding or subtracting!'

slides.prompt: Solve 8 measurement word problems. Show your work, convert units when needed, and check each answer with estimation. Then create your own measurement word problem with an answer key — make it challenging! Use a historical or real-world context.

slides.text: The key to measurement word problems: always make sure you are working with the SAME units before adding, subtracting, or comparing. Convert first, then compute. Estimation helps you check — if your answer seems way off, recheck your work!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student solve multi-step word problems involving metric length measurement and conversion between units?

parent_notes: Word problems combining measurement and conversion are challenging because they require multiple steps. The most common error is operating on numbers with different units (adding cm to m without converting). Encourage your child to always write the units alongside the numbers. Creating their own word problems demonstrates deep understanding — a student who can write a good problem truly understands the concept.

title: Invertebrates — Mollusks
description: Students learn about mollusks: soft-bodied animals that often have shells. They study the three main groups (gastropods, bivalves, cephalopods) and examine shell structures.
instructions:
1. Review: arthropods have exoskeletons and jointed legs. Mollusks are different!
2. Mollusk characteristics: soft body, muscular foot, mantle (may produce a shell), most have a radula (toothed tongue).
3. Three groups:
   - Gastropods: one shell or none, one foot — snails, slugs
   - Bivalves: two shells hinged together — clams, mussels, oysters
   - Cephalopods: tentacles, most intelligent invertebrates — octopus, squid, nautilus
4. Show shells if available. Examine shell structure with magnifying glass.
5. Discuss: octopuses are incredibly intelligent — they can solve puzzles, open jars, and change color!
6. Students draw and label examples from each group.
7. Compare mollusks to arthropods.

slides.setup_instructions: Display seashells for examination. Print clear images of snails, clams, octopus, squid, and nautilus. Have magnifying glasses ready for shell study.

slides.text: 'We have studied arthropods: insects, arachnids, and crustaceans — all with hard exoskeletons and jointed legs. Now meet the MOLLUSKS: soft-bodied animals. Their name comes from the Latin word mollis, meaning soft. Many protect their soft bodies with SHELLS, but some have no shell at all!'

'Three main mollusk groups: GASTROPODS (stomach-foot) include snails and slugs — they glide on a single muscular foot. BIVALVES (two-valves) have two shells hinged together — clams, mussels, and oysters. They open their shells to feed and snap them shut for protection.'

'The most incredible mollusks are CEPHALOPODS (head-foot): octopuses, squid, and nautilus. Their tentacles grow from their heads! Octopuses have no shell at all but are the smartest invertebrates — they can solve puzzles, open jars, escape tanks, and even change color and texture in an instant!' Show images.

slides.prompt: Draw one example from each mollusk group: a gastropod (snail), a bivalve (clam), and a cephalopod (octopus). Label the key body parts: shell, foot, tentacles, mantle. Examine real shells with a magnifying glass and sketch the spiral or hinge patterns you see.

slides.text: Mollusks are the second largest group of invertebrates after arthropods. From the humble garden snail to the brilliant octopus, they show incredible diversity. The beautiful shells you find at the beach were once homes for living mollusks!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student name the three mollusk groups, describe their characteristics, and give examples of each?

parent_notes: If you have seashells at home, this is a wonderful time to examine them closely. Children are often amazed to learn that octopuses are mollusks — related to clams and snails! Octopus intelligence videos on YouTube are incredible and age-appropriate. If you can visit an aquarium or tide pools, the mollusk lesson comes alive. Collect and classify shells at the beach by gastropod vs. bivalve.

title: Geometry — Perimeter of Polygons
description: Students learn the concept of perimeter as the distance around a shape. They measure and calculate the perimeters of various polygons using rulers and addition.
instructions:
1. Introduce perimeter: the distance AROUND the outside of a shape. Peri = around, meter = measure.
2. Walk the perimeter of the room: count steps along each wall, add them up.
3. Demonstrate with a rectangle: measure all 4 sides, add them. P = l + w + l + w = 2l + 2w.
4. For regular shapes (equal sides): P = number of sides x side length.
5. Practice: measure and calculate the perimeter of 5 shapes (rectangle, triangle, pentagon, hexagon, irregular polygon).
6. Word problems: 'A garden is 8 m long and 5 m wide. How much fencing is needed?'
7. Connect to Greek architecture: calculate the perimeter of the Parthenon base.
materials_needed: Polygon shapes (cardboard or paper, various sizes)

slides.setup_instructions: Cut out various polygon shapes from cardboard. Include regular and irregular polygons. Prepare word problems involving perimeter.

slides.text: 'PERIMETER means the distance around the outside of a shape. If an ant walked along every edge of this rectangle and ended up back where it started, the distance it walked is the perimeter! The word comes from Greek: peri (around) + metron (measure). Let us walk the perimeter of our room!'

'To find the perimeter: measure each side and add them all up. This rectangle is 12 cm long and 8 cm wide: P = 12 + 8 + 12 + 8 = 40 cm. Shortcut for rectangles: P = 2 x length + 2 x width = 2(12) + 2(8) = 24 + 16 = 40 cm. Same answer!'

'For REGULAR polygons (all sides equal), it is even easier: just multiply! An equilateral triangle with sides of 5 cm: P = 3 x 5 = 15 cm. A regular hexagon with sides of 4 cm: P = 6 x 4 = 24 cm. But for irregular shapes, you must measure every side and add.' Practice with shapes.

slides.prompt: Measure and calculate the perimeter of 5 shapes using your ruler. Record the length of each side and the total perimeter. Then solve: A Greek temple base is a rectangle 70 m long and 31 m wide. What is the perimeter? How much rope would you need to go around it twice?

slides.text: Perimeter is the distance around any shape. Add up all the sides! For rectangles: P = 2(l + w). For regular polygons: P = sides x length. Perimeter is used whenever you need to know how much material goes AROUND something: fencing, picture frames, borders, and edging.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student measure sides of polygons and calculate their perimeters using addition or multiplication?

parent_notes: Perimeter is a highly practical concept. Help your child find real-world applications: how much ribbon to wrap around a box, how much fencing for a garden, the distance around a picture frame. The distinction between perimeter (around the edge) and area (the space inside, coming in a later week) is important — do not introduce area yet, but if your child asks about the space inside, preview the concept briefly.

title: Greek Theater — Masks and Drama
description: Students learn about the origins of theater in Ancient Greece and create their own theatrical masks. They explore how Greek actors used masks to portray characters and emotions.
instructions:
1. Theater was invented in Ancient Greece! The word 'theater' comes from Greek theatron (viewing place).
2. Greek theaters were semicircular, open-air, and could seat thousands.
3. Actors wore MASKS to show different characters and emotions. Masks amplified their voices.
4. Two main types of plays: TRAGEDY (serious, sad) and COMEDY (funny, lighthearted).
5. The two mask symbols (happy and sad faces) still represent theater today.
6. Students create their own Greek-style masks from paper plates:
   - Choose tragedy or comedy
   - Design the face with exaggerated expression
   - Add hair, headdress, and decorations
7. Perform a short scene wearing the masks.
materials_needed: Yarn or paper strips for hair

slides.setup_instructions: Pre-cut eye holes in paper plates if students are young. Display images of Greek theater masks and amphitheaters. Have all craft materials organized.

slides.text: 'Did you know that THEATER was invented in Ancient Greece? The Greeks built huge open-air theaters cut into hillsides — some could hold 15,000 people! Actors performed plays about myths, heroes, and everyday life. The word theater comes from the Greek word theatron, meaning a place for viewing.'

'Greek actors wore large MASKS to show different characters and emotions. A single actor might play multiple roles by switching masks! The mouths were shaped like megaphones to project the voice. There were two main types of plays: TRAGEDY (serious, often ending sadly) and COMEDY (funny, ending happily). The happy and sad face masks are still the symbol of theater today!'

'Now we create our own Greek theater masks! Choose: will yours show TRAGEDY or COMEDY? For tragedy: downturned mouth, furrowed brow, sad eyes. For comedy: wide smile, raised eyebrows, laughing eyes. Make the expression BIG and exaggerated — the audience far away needs to see it!'

slides.prompt: Create a Greek theater mask: (1) Choose tragedy or comedy. (2) Cut eye holes in a paper plate. (3) Paint or color the face with an exaggerated expression. (4) Add hair with yarn or paper strips. (5) Glue a craft stick to hold it. Then put on your mask and perform a short scene: say 3-4 lines in character!

slides.text: Every time you watch a movie, attend a play, or see actors perform on TV, you are enjoying something that began in Ancient Greece over 2,500 years ago! The Greeks gave us not just theater but also the words: drama, scene, chorus, and orchestra. Your masks connect you to this incredible tradition!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the origins of Greek theater and create a mask representing tragedy or comedy?

parent_notes: Greek theater is the ancestor of all Western performing arts. The mask-making project is highly engaging and can lead to home performances of simplified Greek myths. If possible, watch a short clip of a modern performance of a Greek play. The theater vocabulary is fun: drama, scene, chorus, tragedy, comedy, orchestra — all Greek words we still use. Consider staging a family mythology play with the masks!

title: Poetry — Anthology and Recitation
description: Students compile a personal poetry anthology from the week's work: free verse, couplets, limericks, and haiku. They select their best poem for a memorized recitation performance.
instructions:
1. Gather all poems written this week: free verse, couplets, limericks, haiku.
2. Students select their best work for their anthology. Revise and create final copies.
3. Design a cover for the anthology with a title and illustration.
4. Choose one poem to memorize and recite.
5. Practice recitation techniques: speak clearly, use expression, make eye contact, pause at line breaks.
6. Perform: each student recites their chosen poem for the group/family.
7. Celebrate with a poetry tea: listen to poems while enjoying tea (connecting to China unit!).
materials_needed: Blank booklet or stapled pages for anthology
Optional: tea and treats for poetry tea

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare blank booklets by folding and stapling paper. Gather all poems written throughout the week. Set up a cozy recitation area.

slides.text: 'This week you became a POET! You wrote free verse, couplets, limericks, and haiku. Today we celebrate by creating your very own POETRY ANTHOLOGY — a collection of your best poems — and performing one poem for an audience.'

'First, look through all your poems. Choose your favorites and revise them one more time — fix any spelling, improve a word choice, make it the best it can be. Then copy each poem neatly into your anthology booklet. Illustrate each poem with a small drawing. Design a beautiful cover with a title like My Poems or [Your Name]'s Poetry Collection.'

'Now choose ONE poem to RECITE from memory. Recitation tips: (1) Memorize it line by line, (2) Speak CLEARLY and SLOWLY, (3) Use EXPRESSION — let your voice show the poem's emotion, (4) Make eye contact with your audience, (5) Pause at line breaks to let the words breathe. Practice three times before performing.'

slides.prompt: Compile your poetry anthology: revise your best poems, copy them neatly with illustrations, and design a cover. Then choose one poem, memorize it, and practice reciting it with expression. Perform for your audience!

slides.text: You are a published poet! Your anthology contains original poems in four different forms. Poetry gives us the power to capture moments, express feelings, and play with the music of language. Keep writing poems — you have the skills and the voice!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student compile an organized anthology and recite a poem from memory with expression and clarity?

parent_notes: The poetry anthology is a keepsake worth preserving. Recitation builds confidence, public speaking skills, and deep engagement with language. After today, consider making poetry a regular part of your routine — many families enjoy a weekly poem read aloud at dinner. The ability to memorize and recite poetry is a valuable skill that exercises memory and builds a personal library of beautiful language.

title: Measurement — Review and Mixed Practice
description: Students review all metric length concepts from the week: measuring in cm and m, converting between units, estimating, and solving word problems. They complete a measurement challenge course.
instructions:
1. Quick review: units (mm, cm, m, km), benchmarks, conversion rules.
2. Measurement relay/challenge course: set up 6 stations around the room.
   - Station 1: Measure 3 objects in cm.
   - Station 2: Estimate, then measure 3 objects.
   - Station 3: Convert 5 measurements between cm and m.
   - Station 4: Solve 3 word problems.
   - Station 5: Measure perimeter of 2 shapes.
   - Station 6: Create a measurement word problem.
3. Review answers together.
4. Reflect: what was easy? What needs more practice?

slides.setup_instructions: Set up 6 stations around the room. Each station should have clear instruction cards, necessary tools, and recording sheets. Test each station yourself first.

slides.text: Quick review quiz: 'How many cm in 1 m? How many m in 1 km? What benchmark is about 1 cm? About 1 m? To go from m to cm, do we multiply or divide? By how much?' Rapid-fire review of all concepts.

'Today: a Measurement Challenge Course! Six stations, each testing a different skill. You will measure, estimate, convert, solve word problems, find perimeters, and create your own problem. Record all your work neatly on your recording sheet. Take your time and be precise!'

Explain each station briefly: 'Station 1: measure objects. Station 2: estimate then measure. Station 3: unit conversions. Station 4: word problems. Station 5: perimeter. Station 6: create a word problem. You have about 5 minutes per station. Ready? Begin!'

slides.prompt: Complete all 6 stations of the Measurement Challenge Course. At each station, follow the instructions carefully and record your work. When finished with all stations, review your answers and fix any mistakes. What was your strongest station? What do you want to practice more?

slides.text: Excellent work! You can now measure accurately, convert between metric units, estimate with benchmarks, solve word problems, and calculate perimeters. Measurement is a skill you will use every day for the rest of your life. Next week: mass and capacity!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student demonstrate proficiency in measuring, converting, estimating, and solving problems with metric length?

parent_notes: The challenge course format makes review engaging and active. If setting up 6 stations is not practical at home, simply work through the 6 types of activities sequentially. The key is that your child gets practice with ALL the measurement skills covered this week. Identify any weak areas for additional practice. Next week extends measurement to mass (grams, kilograms) and capacity (liters, milliliters).

title: The Mediterranean World — Trade and Connection
description: Students explore the broader Mediterranean region, understanding how the sea connected diverse civilizations (Egypt, Greece, Phoenicia, Rome) through trade, creating one of history's first interconnected regions.
instructions:
1. Show the Mediterranean Sea on a map: bordered by three continents (Europe, Asia, Africa).
2. Review civilizations around it: Egypt, Greece, Phoenicia (Lebanon), Carthage, Rome (coming later).
3. The Mediterranean as a highway: safer and faster than land travel. Trade connected all these cultures.
4. What was traded: olive oil, wine, pottery, grain, metals, purple dye (Phoenicia), papyrus (Egypt).
5. The Phoenicians invented the alphabet! Letters traveled along trade routes.
6. Students trace Mediterranean trade routes on a map and draw traded goods.
7. Compare to the Silk Road: two great ancient trade networks.
materials_needed: Large map of the Mediterranean region
Blank outline map of the Mediterranean
Yarn or string for tracing trade routes

slides.setup_instructions: Print blank outline maps of the Mediterranean region. Display a large reference map showing all civilizations discussed. Have yarn ready for tracing trade routes.

slides.text: 'Look at the Mediterranean Sea on the map. It is surrounded by THREE continents: Europe to the north, Asia to the east, and Africa to the south. The word Mediterranean means middle of the Earth — the ancient world literally revolved around this sea!'

'Look at all the civilizations we have studied around its shores: Egypt here in the south, Greece here, and soon we will learn about Rome here. The PHOENICIANS lived here in modern Lebanon — they were the greatest sailors of the ancient world and they invented the ALPHABET that our letters come from! All these civilizations were connected by the sea.'

'Ships carried goods across the Mediterranean: olive oil and pottery from Greece, grain from Egypt, purple dye from Phoenicia, metals from Spain. But they also carried IDEAS: the Phoenician alphabet, Greek philosophy, Egyptian mathematics. Trade connected and enriched every culture it touched — just like the Silk Road connected East and West!'

slides.prompt: On your outline map: (1) Label all three continents and the Mediterranean Sea. (2) Mark and label: Egypt, Greece, Phoenicia, Carthage, Rome (for later!). (3) Draw trade routes connecting them across the sea. (4) At each civilization, write or draw 2 goods they traded. (5) Compare: how is Mediterranean trade similar to the Silk Road?

slides.text: The Mediterranean Sea was the ancient world's greatest connector. Civilizations that might have remained isolated instead shared goods, ideas, and culture across the water. The alphabet you use to write came from the Phoenicians, across the Mediterranean to the Greeks, and eventually to us!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify civilizations around the Mediterranean, describe trade connections, and compare to the Silk Road?

parent_notes: This lesson synthesizes previous studies by showing how all the ancient civilizations were connected. The Mediterranean as a 'highway' is a powerful concept. The Phoenician alphabet origin is particularly fascinating — our letter A comes from the Phoenician aleph (ox), turned upside down! This lesson sets up the coming study of Rome, which eventually dominated the entire Mediterranean world.

title: Greek Contributions — Architecture and Language
description: Students explore the lasting contributions of Ancient Greece to architecture (columns, the Parthenon) and language (Greek roots in English words). They discover how much of modern life has Greek origins.
instructions:
1. Greek architecture: three column styles — Doric (simple), Ionic (scrolls), Corinthian (leaves).
2. Show images of each column type. Find them in modern buildings (courthouses, museums, banks).
3. The Parthenon: temple to Athena in Athens. Perfect proportions, Doric columns.
4. Greek roots in English: graph (write), tele (far), phon (sound), bio (life), geo (earth).
5. Word-building game: combine Greek roots to make words (telephone, biography, geography, television).
6. Students draw all three column types and label them.
7. Create a Greek Root Word Web: one root in the center, words branching out.
materials_needed: Images of Greek columns and the Parthenon
Images of modern buildings with Greek-style columns

slides.setup_instructions: Print images of Doric, Ionic, and Corinthian columns side by side. Find photos of local or famous buildings with Greek-style columns. Prepare a Greek root word reference sheet.

slides.text: 'Ancient Greece gave us SO much that we still use today! Look at this building — see the tall columns? That style comes from Greece! There are three types: DORIC (simple and strong, like a plain cylinder), IONIC (with spiral scrolls at the top), and CORINTHIAN (decorated with carved leaves). You can spot these on courthouses, banks, and museums!'

'The most famous Greek building is the PARTHENON — a temple to the goddess Athena on a hilltop in Athens. It is considered one of the most perfect buildings ever constructed. Its proportions are so precise that it has influenced architecture for 2,500 years.' Show images and point out the Doric columns.

'Greece also gave us thousands of WORDS! Many English words have Greek roots. TELE means far, PHONE means sound — telephone means far-sound! BIO means life, GRAPH means write — biography means life-writing! GEO means earth, GRAPH means write — geography means earth-writing!' Build words on the board like a puzzle.

slides.prompt: Part 1: Draw all three column types (Doric, Ionic, Corinthian) and label each with its name and key feature. Part 2: Create a Greek Root Word Web. Choose a root (tele, graph, bio, geo, phon, or scope) and write it in the center. Branch out with all the English words you can think of that use that root.

slides.text: Greek contributions surround us every day: in our buildings, our words, our government, our sports, our theater, and our thinking. Next week, we continue with Greek philosophy and Alexander the Great — two more incredible Greek contributions to the world!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the three Greek column types and use Greek roots to explain the meaning of English words?

parent_notes: Greek roots are an incredibly powerful vocabulary tool. Once children learn common roots (tele, phone, graph, bio, geo, scope, micro, auto), they can decode hundreds of unfamiliar words. Make this a family game: spot a new word, find the Greek root, figure out the meaning. The column identification is also fun — go for a walk and find Greek-style columns on buildings in your area. They are everywhere!

title: Read Aloud — Greek Myth: Icarus and Daedalus
description: A read-aloud of the myth of Icarus and Daedalus, exploring themes of ambition, hubris (excessive pride), and the consequences of ignoring wise counsel. Students discuss the moral and connect to science (flight).
instructions:
1. Set the context: Daedalus was a brilliant inventor trapped on the island of Crete (connect to Theseus story — same labyrinth!).
2. Read the myth aloud: Daedalus builds wings of feathers and wax. He warns Icarus not to fly too high (sun) or too low (sea).
3. Icarus ignores the warning, flies too close to the sun, wax melts, he falls.
4. Discuss: Why did Icarus fly too high? (excitement, ambition, ignoring warnings).
5. The concept of HUBRIS: excessive pride or confidence that leads to downfall.
6. Science connection: Why would wax melt in heat? What makes flight possible?
7. Students write: 'The lesson of Icarus is...' and draw a key scene.
materials_needed: Greek mythology book with Icarus story

slides.setup_instructions: Select an age-appropriate version of the Icarus myth. Have the map visible to show Crete — the same island from the Minotaur story!

slides.text: 'Remember the island of Crete from the Theseus story? After Theseus escaped the labyrinth, King Minos was furious. He locked up DAEDALUS — the brilliant inventor who built the labyrinth — and his son ICARUS. They were trapped on the island. How could they escape when Minos controlled the seas?'

Read the myth with dramatic expression. Build tension as Daedalus constructs the wings. Emphasize Daedalus's warning: 'Do not fly too close to the sun, or the wax will melt. Do not fly too low, or the sea spray will weigh down the feathers. Follow me, stay in the middle.' Pause: 'Do you think Icarus will listen?'

After reading: 'Why did Icarus fly too high? He was so excited by the feeling of flying that he forgot his father's warning. The Greeks called this HUBRIS — thinking you are above the rules, that warnings do not apply to you. Many Greek myths warn against hubris. It is still a lesson we need today.'

slides.prompt: In your reading journal: (1) Draw the most dramatic moment of the myth. (2) Write: 'The lesson of the Icarus myth is...' in at least 3 sentences. (3) Answer: Can you think of a time when someone warned you about something and you wished you had listened? What happened?

slides.text: The story of Icarus has been told for over 2,500 years because its lesson is timeless: listen to wise advice, know your limits, and beware of hubris. Daedalus represents wisdom and experience; Icarus represents youth and recklessness. Both characters live inside each of us.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student retell the Icarus myth, explain the concept of hubris, and articulate the story's moral?

parent_notes: The Icarus myth is one of the most powerful stories in Western literature. The concept of hubris appears throughout Greek mythology and is still relevant. Children naturally connect to the idea of ignoring warnings — they do it themselves! This is a great springboard for a deeper conversation about why we sometimes ignore advice even when we know it is wise. The science connection (wax melting, flight mechanics) adds another dimension.
